discussion.content: Correct: Android Enterprise -> Device restrictions -> General -> System update -> maintenance window

Selected Answer: B
"Maintenance Window" can be setup from General.
Intune --> Devices --> Configuration --> Create New Policy --> Android Enterprise --> Device restrictions --> General --> System update: Maintenance window.

Selected Answer: A
In Microsoft Intune, when configuring a Device restrictions profile for corporate-owned, fully managed Android Enterprise devices, the Device experience section contains settings related to system updates, including:
•System update type (Automatic, Postponed, Maintenance window)
•Maintenance window start and end times
This setting ensures updates occur during designated time windows, reducing disruptions to users.

Selected Answer: B
Tested it

Selected Answer: B
Correct. Tested in Client's tenancy.

I have just spent an hour checking every setting in a device restrictions template and none of these answers are correct.
Device Experience: Doesn't exist as category in standard device restriction template
General: Screen cap, Copy paste, man. unenrol, man. root cert install, camera, onedrive file sync, removable storage, geolocation, internet sharing, phone reset, usb connection, antitheft mode, Cortana, voice recording, device name mod, add provisioning packages, remove prov pack, device discovery, task switcher, sim card error, ink workspace, autopilot reset, require network during setup, DMA, End process from task man. 
Connectivity: Bunch of wifi and bluetooth settings, no maintenance window.
Power Settings: Plugged in and on battery behaviours, no maintenance window.

You can do this with a config policy through the settings catalogue and WUfB but as it stands I don't think this question makes much sense.

comments.content: Wrote above thinking this was on a windows 10 device but it's actually Android enterprise. Checked in tenant and now agree with given answer (General -> system update: Maintenance Window)

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune. The subscription contains corporate-owned, fully managed Android Enterprise devices.

You plan to deploy a configuration profile that will have a device restrictions profile type named Profile1. Profile1 will assign maintenance windows for system updates.

What should you configure from the Configuration settings for Profile1?

HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

You use Microsoft Intune to manage Windows 365 Cloud PC devices.

You need to deploy a Windows 365 Security Baseline to the Cloud PC devices. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• Block data execution prevention.
• Enable virtualization-based security (VBS) and Secure Boot.

What should you configure for the Windows 365 Security Baseline profile? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Checked in tenant answers are correct:
File explorer -> data execution prevention
Device Guard -> VBS options are: Not configured, VBS with secureboot, VBS with secureboot and DMA

Given answer is correct.
File Explorer
"Turn off Data Execution Prevention for Explorer
Baseline default: Disabled"
Ref:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/security-baseline-settings-windows-365?pivots=win365-24h1#:~:text=Turn%20off%20Data%20Execution%20Prevention%20for%20Explorer%0ABaseline%20default%3A%20Disabled

Device Guard
"Enable Virtualization Based Security
Baseline default: Enable virtualization based security."
Ref:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/security-baseline-settings-windows-365?pivots=win365-24h1#:~:text=Enable%20Virtualization%20Based%20Security%0ABaseline%20default%3A%20Enable%20virtualization%20based%20security.

In the context of Windows 365 Cloud PC devices, if you need to disable Data Execution Prevention (DEP), you should be looking at the "Microsoft Defender Antivirus" configuration within the Windows 365 Security Baseline profile. DEP is related to memory protection settings managed by Microsoft Defender Exploit Guard, which is part of the broader Microsoft Defender security suite.

To enable virtualization-based security (VBS) and Secure Boot for Cloud PC devices using the Windows 365 Security Baseline profile, you need to focus on the configuration of System Guard (Device Guard) and System Security settings rather than only Microsoft Defender.

comments.content: To block or disable Data Execution Prevention (DEP) in a Windows environment, the relevant setting would not typically be related to Microsoft Edge. Instead, it falls under system-level and security configurations, often managed by Windows Defender (or Microsoft Defender in modern terminology).

discussion.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/security-baseline-settings-windows-365?pivots=win365-24h1 
Answers are correct

Selected Answer: A
Modifying whom the policy is assigned to, assignments, does not effect the outcome.

Selected Answer: A
CAP is the right answer.

Selected Answer: A
Creating a Conditional Access policy, you can enforce the use of Microsoft apps for email access. You can configure the policy to require users to use an Intune-managed app (like Outlook Mobile) to access email services. This will prevent users from using unmanaged email clients and indirectly address the screen capture issue.

Conditional Access seems the most logical. ie, block access from anything not approved.

Assignments refers to who(users/devices) the policy applies to, so it can't be D.

Selected Answer: A
Should be CA.

choices.C: Modify the Data protection settings of Policy1.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune.

You create a new Android app protection policy named Policy1 that prevents screen captures in all Microsoft apps.

You discover that an unmanaged email client installed on Android devices can still capture screens.

You need to ensure that users can only use Microsoft apps to access email.

What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
An app protection policy can protect all apps shown in the answer choices (Outlook, OneDrive, Teams, Edge).

I imagine there is a type mistake, the correct question is:

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription. All Windows devices are enrolled in Microsoft Intune. You need to create a device configuration policy named Policy1 and apply Policy1 to the devices. What can you protect by using Policy1?

a. Microsoft Outlook
b. Microsoft OneDrive
c. Microsoft Teams
d. Microsoft Edge

Then option D is the perfect choice.

Selected Answer: D
For Windows platform, app protection only covers Edge, tested on Tenant

Fellas - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy

:) You can do 'em for all.

Selected Answer: D
"You can enable protected MAM access to org data via Microsoft Edge on personal Windows devices."

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy-settings-windows

discussion.content:

D Edge is correct

Selected Answer: D
Test when you create new app protection policy the only app that i can choose is Edge.

I think there was a "NO" missing here.
It works for Office 365 apps. Outlook is an Office App. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy#app-protection-policies-for-microsoft-365-office-apps. I vote A.

comments.content: The question is not asking for what you think is the best app to protect. You need to be accurate.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Outlook is the primary application for handling email, and therefore, it's the most suitable target for an app protection policy to safeguard sensitive email data.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

All Windows devices are enrolled in Microsoft Intune.

You need to create an app protection policy named Policy1 and apply Policy1 to the devices.

What can you protect by using Policy1?

choices.B: Add a scope tag to Profile1.
choices.C: Configure ASR Only Per Rule Exclusions in Profile1.
choices.D: Create a device compliance policy and assign the policy to all the devices.
choices.A: Create an Endpoint Privilege Management policy and assign the policy to all the devices.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C seems corret
C seems corret

Answer appears correct.

Endpoint Privilege Management policy enables users to run tasks requiring elevated privilege without administrator rights.
Scope tags determine which objects admins can see.
Device Compliance Policy wouldn't impact ASR policy

Selected Answer: C
Only C makes sense in the context of the question, seems correct.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

You use Microsoft Intune to manage all Windows 11 devices.

You create an attack surface reduction (ASR) policy named Profile1 based on the Attack Surface Reduction Rules profile and assign Profile1 to all the devices.

A user reports that an Adobe Reader plug-in is now blocked.

You need to ensure that the plug-in is unblocked.

What should you do?
